clinical_study.brief_title: Femtosecond Laser-assisted Corneal Debridement for Herpes Simplex Keratitis
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial of Corneal Debridement for the Treatment of Herpes Simplex Epithelial Keratitis

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the study is to learn if adding femtosecond laser-assisted corneal debridement to a standard therapy of oral ganciclovir can help shorten the healing time of herpes simplex epithelial keratitis (HSK).

primary_outcome.description: Time to complete corneal epithelial healing

secondary_outcome.description: Assessing complete corneal re-epithelization at day 14±1 using slit-lamp microcopy
Assessing corneal opacity and vascularization using slit-lamp microcopy
Assessing best-corrected visual acuity using ETDRS chart
Assessing changes of corneal power and astigmatism using autorefractor keratometer
Assessing corneal sensation using Cochet-Bonnet esthesiometer
Assessing recurrent HSK using slit-lamp microcopy

arm_group.description: Femtosecond laser-assisted cornea debridement (FLDEB) combined with ganciclovir (GCV) orally.

intervention.description: The eye will be anesthetized, and femtosecond laser technology will be used to remove epithelial tissue (diameter: 8mm; depth: 100micron) that includes the loosened diseased corneal epithelial cells. Antibiotic ointments and drops will be instilled postoperatively.
Patient will be treated with GCV orally (200mg, 3 times a day, for 14 days).
A commercial femtosecond laser to create a particular shaped graft for transplantation.
